info: This is a generic diagnostic trouble code (DTC) and applies to many OBD-II vehicles (1996-newer). That may include but is not limited to vehicles from Mazda, Nissan, Land Rover, Chrysler, Ford, Dodge, GMC, etc. Although generic, the exact repair steps may vary depending on year, make, model, and powertrain configuration.
A stored code P065C means that the powertrain control module (PCM), or one of the other related controllers, has detected a low output condition in the generator system.

In some cases, the alternator is called the generator but more frequently this type of code is used in a hybrid or electric vehicle which produces sustained electrical power from a generator. The generator may be driven by the engine or any of the drive wheels.

The PCM monitors generator output voltage and amperage at varying RPM levels and load degrees and calculates voltage requirements accordingly. In addition to monitoring generator output (performance), the PCM is also responsible for providing a signal that activates the generator lamp in the event of low output.
If a problem is detected in monitoring generator performance, a code P065C will be stored and a malfunction indicator lamp (MIL) may be illuminated.
symptoms:
Delayed or no start
Electrical accessories may be inoperative
Engine drivability issues
causes:
Defective generator
Bad fuse, relay, or fusible link
Open or shorted circuit between the PCM and generator
PCM programming error
Faulty controller or PCM
